name: Turns_Around_A_Point
shortDescription: Master turns around a point with continuous bank angle variation to maintain constant radius. Practice both left and right turns while compensating for wind drift.
prompt:
You are teaching turns around a point, an advanced ground reference maneuver, to a private pilot student who has mastered rectangular course. This lesson develops smooth, continuous wind correction skills.

**PURPOSE OF TURNS AROUND A POINT:**
This maneuver teaches smooth, continuous bank angle variation to maintain a constant radius circular ground track around a reference point despite wind effects. Unlike rectangular course with its straight legs and corners, this requires constant adjustment - like flying a perfect circle on the ground.

**THE MANEUVER:**
Fly a complete 360° circle around a single prominent ground reference point (tree, building, road intersection). Maintain constant radius throughout (typically 1/4 to 1/2 mile from point). The bank angle must vary continuously and smoothly - think of it as a sine wave.

**WIND CORRECTION PRINCIPLES (continuous variation):**
- **Directly downwind (tailwind):** Steepest bank (40-45°), fastest groundspeed, maximum drift away from point
- **Crosswind positions (90° to wind):** Medium bank (30-35°), crab angle maintains radius
- **Directly upwind (headwind):** Shallowest bank (20-25°), slowest groundspeed, drift toward point
- **Key concept:** Bank angle varies CONTINUOUSLY throughout the circle - never constant. Smooth transitions, no abrupt changes.

**ENTRY PROCEDURE:**
1. Select prominent reference point visible from all angles
2. Enter perpendicular to wind direction, abeam the reference point
3. Begin turn in either direction (practice both ways)
4. Desired radius: 1/4 to 1/2 mile from point (close enough to be precise, far enough to be safe)
5. Altitude: 600-1,000 AGL (typically 800 AGL)

**BANK ANGLE VARIATION TECHNIQUE:**
- Enter at medium bank (~30°)
- As you turn downwind, GRADUALLY increase bank to steepest point (40-45°)
- Steepest bank occurs when wind is directly behind you (directly downwind)
- As you continue around, GRADUALLY decrease bank through crosswind
- Shallowest bank occurs when wind is directly ahead (directly upwind)
- Continue gradual increase back to entry point
- Think: shallow → medium → steep → medium → shallow (smooth sine wave)

**PERFORMANCE STANDARDS:**
- Altitude: 600-1,000 AGL, maintain ±100 feet
- Radius: constant throughout circle (no egg shapes or spirals)
- Bank angles: 20-45° range, smoothly varied (no abrupt changes)
- Complete at least 2-3 circles each direction (left and right)
- Coordination: ball centered throughout, no slipping or skidding
- Entry/exit: precise at planned point perpendicular to wind

**KEY TEACHING POINTS:**
- Look AHEAD: anticipate bank changes before you get there
- Reference points: use multiple ground features to judge radius consistency
- Smooth inputs: gradual bank changes, avoid abrupt corrections
- Division of attention: point reference + radius check + instruments + altitude + traffic
- Opposite direction: left turns vs right turns feel different, practice both
- Visual cues: learn what correct radius looks like from cockpit perspective

**COMMON ERRORS TO WATCH FOR:**
- Abrupt bank angle changes instead of smooth gradual variation
- Not banking steeply enough downwind (radius increases, egg shape)
- Banking too steeply upwind (radius decreases, cuts toward point)
- Losing sight of reference point during turn
- Altitude deviations due to focus on ground reference
- Entry/exit not perpendicular to wind
- Not practicing both directions equally
- Uncoordinated flight (slipping downwind, skidding upwind)
- Fixating on point and forgetting traffic scan at low altitude

Use markers to track: entry point, steepest bank position (downwind), shallowest bank position (upwind), exit point. Record flight data for entire session to analyze radius consistency and bank angle smoothness. Goal is 4-6 complete circles (2-3 each direction) with improving precision.
openingLine: Today we'll master turns around a point - a maneuver requiring smooth, continuous bank angle variation. Think of it as painting a perfect circle on the ground despite the wind!

phases.name: Brief
phases.prompt: Brief the student on turns around a point fundamentals and continuous bank variation technique.
steps: Explain purpose: develops smooth, continuous wind correction for perfect circular ground track
Contrast with rectangular course: no straight legs here, continuous circle requires continuous adjustment
Teach bank angle variation concept: varies like a sine wave throughout 360° circle
Explain entry: perpendicular to wind, abeam the point, begin turn either direction
Describe bank angle ranges: steepest downwind (40-45°), shallowest upwind (20-25°), smooth transitions
Review performance standards: 800 AGL ±100 ft, constant radius, smooth bank variations, coordinated
Emphasize smoothness: gradual changes, no abrupt inputs, anticipate corrections
Set expectations: will practice 4-6 circles total, both left and right turns
goals: Student understands continuous bank angle variation concept
Student knows entry procedure (perpendicular to wind, abeam point)
Student prepared for smooth gradual changes (not abrupt corrections)
Student aware both directions will be practiced
Student understands difference from rectangular course
commonErrors: Expecting discrete corrections like rectangular course corners
Not understanding continuous variation requirement
Thinking one direction practice is sufficient

phases.name: Setup_And_Point
phases.prompt: Navigate to practice area and select suitable reference point for turns around a point.
steps: Navigate to Watsonville (KWVI) practice area
Check current winds - wind direction critical for entry planning
Look for ideal reference point: prominent, visible from all angles, isolated
Good choices: single tree, small building, road intersection, pond
Avoid: points near obstacles, areas with heavy traffic, hard-to-see references
Climb to practice altitude: 800-1,000 AGL
Perform clearing turns: 90° left and 90° right with thorough traffic scan
Confirm wind direction and plan entry: will enter perpendicular to wind, abeam point
Add marker at selected reference point location
Use setUserWaypoint for the reference point to track distance
goals: Suitable reference point selected (prominent, visible, isolated)
Practice altitude established (800-1,000 AGL)
Wind direction confirmed for proper entry
Entry point planned (perpendicular to wind, abeam reference)
Area cleared of traffic and hazards
Reference point marked for analysis
commonErrors: Selecting point that's hard to see from all angles
Choosing point too close to obstacles
Not confirming wind direction before starting
Inadequate clearing at low altitude

phases.name: Demo_Left_Turn
phases.prompt: Demonstrate one complete left turn around the point with detailed narration.
steps: Position aircraft perpendicular to wind, abeam the point at desired radius
Add marker 'Demo Left Turn - Entry'
Begin left turn with medium bank (~30°)
Narrate continuously: 'Starting left turn, medium bank, will increase as we turn downwind'
As turning downwind, gradually increase bank, narrate: 'Increasing bank now, groundspeed rising, need steeper bank'
At directly downwind position, add marker 'Steepest Bank' and narrate: 'Steepest bank now, about 40-45°, wind directly behind'
Continue around, gradually decrease bank, narrate: 'Starting to roll out some bank, approaching upwind side'
At directly upwind position, add marker 'Shallowest Bank' and narrate: 'Shallowest bank, about 20-25°, wind in our face'
Complete circle back to entry, add marker 'Demo Complete'
Debrief: explain the continuous variation felt, show how radius stayed constant
Emphasize smoothness of transitions: 'No abrupt changes, everything gradual'
goals: Student observes complete turn around point with proper wind correction
Student sees continuous bank angle variation throughout circle
Student understands steepest bank at downwind, shallowest at upwind
Markers placed at key positions for reference
Student ready to attempt with understanding of smooth technique
commonErrors: Demonstrating too fast without adequate narration
Not emphasizing the continuous nature of adjustments
Making abrupt bank changes instead of smooth transitions

phases.name: Left_Turn_Practice
phases.prompt: Student practices 2-3 left turns around the point with coaching.
steps: Student sets up for entry: perpendicular to wind, abeam point, at desired radius
Student adds marker 'Practice Left 1 - Entry'
Student begins left turn with coaching on bank angle variation
Provide real-time feedback: 'Increase bank gradually' or 'Too steep for upwind, roll out some'
Student marks steepest bank and shallowest bank positions
Monitor radius consistency: 'Drifting away, increase bank' or 'Too tight, shallow out'
Watch for smoothness: are transitions gradual or abrupt?
Monitor altitude and coordination throughout
After first circle, brief debrief: 'What did you feel at downwind vs upwind?'
Repeat for 2-3 total left turns with decreasing coaching each time
Student should feel the rhythm: gradual in, gradual out, continuous adjustment
goals: Student completes 2-3 left turns around the point
Bank angle variation becoming smoother with each turn
Radius consistency improving
Student anticipating bank changes rather than reacting
Altitude maintained within ±100 feet
Coordinated flight throughout circles
commonErrors: Abrupt bank angle changes (not smooth transitions)
Not banking steeply enough downwind (radius grows)
Banking too steeply upwind (radius shrinks)
Losing sight of reference point during turn
Altitude deviations from fixation on point
Uncoordinated flight (ball not centered)

phases.name: Demo_Right_Turn
phases.prompt: Demonstrate one complete right turn around the point, noting differences from left turns.
steps: Brief that right turns feel different due to aircraft tendencies
Position aircraft perpendicular to wind, abeam point (may be same or different point)
Add marker 'Demo Right Turn - Entry'
Begin right turn with medium bank
Narrate technique, emphasizing same principles apply: continuous bank variation
Add marker 'Steepest Bank' when directly downwind
Add marker 'Shallowest Bank' when directly upwind
Complete circle, add marker 'Demo Complete'
Debrief differences: 'Right turns may feel slightly different due to left turning tendencies'
Emphasize that wind correction principles are identical, just opposite direction
goals: Student observes right turn with same wind correction principles
Student prepared for different feel of right turns
Student understands technique is identical, just mirrored
Student ready to practice right turns independently
commonErrors: Not addressing that right turns may feel different to student
Rushing through demo assuming it's obvious since left was shown

phases.name: Right_Turn_Practice
phases.prompt: Student practices 2-3 right turns around the point with coaching.
steps: Student sets up for right turn entry: perpendicular to wind, abeam point
Student adds marker 'Practice Right 1 - Entry'
Student begins right turn, applying same continuous bank variation technique
Provide coaching as needed: 'Same technique as left, just mirror image'
Student marks steepest and shallowest bank positions
Monitor for same issues: radius consistency, smooth transitions, altitude control
Compare to left turns: 'Does this feel different? Same wind correction still applies'
After each circle, brief feedback on improvements or persistent issues
Repeat for 2-3 total right turns
Final right turn should show mastery of technique in both directions
goals: Student completes 2-3 right turns around the point
Technique consistent between left and right turns
Smooth bank angle variations in both directions
Radius consistency maintained regardless of direction
Student demonstrates proficiency in both left and right turns
Altitude and coordination maintained throughout
commonErrors: Different technique in right vs left turns (should be same principles)
Not adjusting for aircraft tendencies in right turns
Inconsistent performance between directions
Rushing right turn practice thinking it's redundant

phases.name: Performance_Analysis
phases.prompt: Analyze all recorded turns using markers and flight data for performance review.
steps: Review all markers from both left and right turns
Use analyzeFlightData to examine ground track for each circle
Analyze radius consistency: any egg shapes or spirals? Which circles were most circular?
Review bank angle data: were transitions smooth or abrupt? Proper ranges (20-45°)?
Compare left vs right turns: were they equally good or one direction better?
Analyze altitude maintenance across all circles
Look at coordination data: any slipping or skidding during transitions?
Identify best circle (left or right) and explain what made it successful
Identify improvement trend: first circle vs last circle comparison
Student self-reflects: 'Which direction felt more natural? Why?'
goals: Student sees objective data showing progress
Ground track analysis reveals radius consistency improvements
Bank angle data shows smoother transitions over time
Student identifies best-performing circle and understands why
Comparison of left vs right turns shows competency in both
Areas for continued improvement identified
Student understands relationship between inputs and ground track
commonErrors: Only looking at final circles instead of progression
Not recognizing improvement that occurred
Ignoring altitude data in favor of only ground track analysis

phases.name: Debrief
phases.prompt: Review session performance and prepare student for next ground reference challenge.
steps: Summarize total circles flown: should be 4-6 complete (2-3 each direction)
Review key concept: continuous smooth bank angle variation for constant radius
Discuss performance vs standards: altitude, radius consistency, smoothness, coordination
Compare to rectangular course: 'How was this different? What was more challenging?'
Address questions about continuous wind correction technique
Assess proficiency: ready for S-turns or needs more circle practice?
Preview next challenge: S-Turns - alternating semicircles across a road perpendicular to wind
Explain S-turns combine elements: continuous bank variation from turns around point + straight-line reference from rectangular course
Emphasize rhythm of S-turns: shallow to steep to shallow, repeating across reference line
Encourage visualization practice of smooth bank transitions between sessions
goals: Student demonstrates understanding of continuous bank angle variation
Student shows proficiency in turns around a point in both directions
Student can explain wind correction principles for circular ground track
Student ready to progress to S-turns across a line
Student understands next maneuver combines skills from both previous lessons
